bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: persons exempted from sections 19 (5) and 62 (1) of the Act by section 177 of this regulation and the manufacturer of the related liquor as defined in that section;
persons exempted from sections 19 (5) and 62 (1) of the Act by section 178 of this regulation;
persons exempted from section 19 (5) (b) of the Act by section 179 of this regulation;
persons exempted from section 19 (5) (b) of the Act by section 180 of this regulation and the small manufacturer as defined in that section;
persons exempted from section 62 (1) of the Act by section 181 of this regulation;
an employee of any person or manufacturer referred to in paragraphs (a) to (e).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the conditions referred to in subsection (3), the persons and manufacturers referred to in subsection (1) are exempt from section 62 (2) of the Act in respect of liquor to which the exemptions referred to in subsection (1) (a) to (e) of this section apply.
The general manager may impose conditions on an exemption referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 182 does not restrict the general manager's power under section 62 (3) (a) of the Act to exempt a person from section 62 (2) of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The general manager may establish the following training programs for the purposes of section 60 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Serving it Right: The Responsible Beverage Service Program;
Special Event Server Program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The SIR program and SES program may be provided by the general manager or a person or organization approved by the general manager.
A person or organization that provides the SIR program or SES program must give each candidate who successfully completes the program a certificate of completion.
The certificate of completion given to a person under subsection (3) expires 5 years after the person successfully completes the program, and the certificate must show the expiry date.
A certificate of completion that is valid on the date this section comes into force that does not show an expiry date expires on September 15, 2020.

For the purposes of section 60 (1) of the Act, the SIR program is the prescribed training program for a licensee who holds any of the following licences and a person who, in accordance with section 18 of the Act, uses any of the following licences:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: liquor primary licence;
food primary licence;
catering licence;
manufacturer licence;
licensee retail store licence;
wine store licence, except a wine store licence that authorizes only the sale of wine for sacramental purposes;
special wine store licence;
rural licensee retail store licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 60 (1) of the Act, the SIR program is the prescribed training program for a permittee who holds a special event permit if the number of people attending the event is expected to be 500 or more per day.

For the purposes of section 60 (1) of the Act, the SES program is the prescribed training program for a permittee who holds a special event permit if the number of people attending the event is expected to be less than 500 per day.
The prescribed training programs for the purposes of section 60 (2) (a) of the Act are as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the liquor is sold or served in the service area under a special event permit, the SIR program or SES program;
in all other cases, the SIR program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The prescribed training programs for the purposes of section 60 (2) (b) of the Act are as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the liquor is sold or served in the service area under a special event permit and the number of people attending the event is expected to be less than 500 per day, the SIR program or SES program;
in all other cases, the SIR program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who sells or serves liquor, or supervises the sale or service of liquor, in a duty free store that is a ship chandler is exempt from the requirement to complete a training program or recertification under section 60 (2) of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemption in respect of foreign manufacturers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, "foreign manufacturer" means a manufacturer that does not manufacture liquor in Canada.
This section applies to a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: represents a foreign manufacturer, other than a licensed agent, and
is not a resident of Canada.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person described in subsection (2) is exempt from the requirement to successfully complete a prescribed training program or recertification under section 60 (2) (a) of the Act when the person serves liquor of the foreign manufacturer at an event described in subsection (4) of this section if the person is supervised at the event by a person who has successfully completed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the SIR program or SES program, and
if applicable, any recertification required by section 190 of this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) applies to an event that involves the conduct of tastings of the liquor of the foreign manufacturer and that is held at a liquor store or in a service area.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prescribed persons and programs — section 60 (3) of Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are the prescribed persons for the purposes of section 60 (3) of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an employee who serves drinks containing liquor under section 86 (2) of this regulation and the person who supervises the service of those drinks;
a licensed agent and the staff of the licensee who serve samples of liquor;

a person who sells or serves liquor at an assisted living residence, community care facility or hospital, as those terms are defined in section 9 (1) of the Act, and the person who supervises the sale and service of the liquor.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The prescribed training program for the purposes of section 60 (3) of the Act is the SIR program.
This section applies to the following persons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who sells or serves liquor;
a permittee who holds a special event permit if the number of people attending the event is expected to be less than 500 per day;
a person who supervises the sale or service of liquor in the service area under a special event permit if the number of people attending the event is expected to be less than 500 per day.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person referred to in subsection (1) is exempt from the requirement to successfully complete the prescribed training program or recertification under section 60 (1) and (2) of the Act for the period specified in subsection (3) of this section if the person provides evidence satisfactory to the general manager that the person has successfully completed a liquor service training program offered by another province.
A person referred to in subsection (1) is exempt

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a person whose training completion document from the other province shows an expiry date, until that expiry date;

in the case of a person whose training completion document from the other province does not show an expiry date, September 15, 2020 or 5 years from the date the document was issued, whichever is later.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a person has successfully completed a prescribed training program for the purposes of section 60 of the Act and the person's certificate of completion in respect of the training program has expired, recertification involves the person successfully completing the same prescribed training program.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Activities Allowed Without a Licence or Permit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may manufacture liquor without a licence or permit for the following purposes if the conditions set out in subsection (2) are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the liquor is manufactured for an educational or scientific purpose;
the liquor is manufactured to test equipment used in the manufacture of liquor and the person also manufactures the equipment;
the person manufactures beer or wine-making kits and the liquor is manufactured when testing the kits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The conditions referred to in subsection (1) are as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is authorized to manufacture the liquor under the Excise Act, 2001 (Canada) or the Excise Act (Canada);
the liquor that is manufactured is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: consumed or used for the purpose for which it was manufactured, or
disposed of as waste;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the liquor is consumed, the persons consuming the liquor are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: employees of the manufacturer, or
students who are enrolled in a course to learn how to manufacture liquor;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the liquor is consumed, the person who manufactures the liquor does not charge for the liquor that is consumed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who consumes liquor in accordance with subsection (2) (b) and (c) may possess the liquor in an open container in the facilities used to manufacture the liquor.
In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: dentist means a dentist registered with the British Columbia College of Oral Health Professionals established under the Health Professions Act;
hospital has the same meaning as in section 9 (1) of the Act;
pharmacist has the same meaning as in section 25.8 of the Health Professions Act;
veterinarian means an individual who is registered under the Veterinarians Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may manufacture ethyl alcohol without a licence or permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ethyl alcohol is manufactured as part of the person's business, and
the person is authorized to manufacture the ethyl alcohol under the Excise Act, 2001 (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is authorized to manufacture ethyl alcohol under subsection (2) may sell the ethyl alcohol without a licence or permit to a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who holds an ethyl alcohol purchase permit,
who is authorized under subsection (6) to purchase the ethyl alcohol, or
who is authorized under the Excise Act, 2001 (Canada) to purchase the ethyl alcohol.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who sells ethyl alcohol to a person who holds an ethyl alcohol purchase permit must not sell to the permittee a quantity of ethyl alcohol that exceeds the quantity authorized by the permit.
A pharmacist may sell ethyl alcohol without a licence or permit to medical practitioners and hospitals as a sterilizing product.
The following persons, in the following circumstances, may purchase ethyl alcohol without a licence or permit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pharmacist, if the ethyl alcohol is for use only in connection with the person's pharmacy business

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in compounding medicines,
as a solvent or preservative, or
for sale to medical practitioners and hospitals as a sterilizing product;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a dentist, medical practitioner, nurse practitioner, registrant of the College of Naturopathic Physicians of British Columbia or veterinarian, if the ethyl alcohol is for use only in connection with the person's practice;
a hospital, if the ethyl alcohol is for use only in the hospital;
a university, if the ethyl alcohol is for use for scientific purposes;
the government or Canada;
a person who holds a prescription, as defined in section 1 of the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act, for ethyl alcohol.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: health authority means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a regional health board designated under section 4 of the Health Authorities Act,
the First Nations Health Authority, or
the Provincial Health Services Authority;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: managed alcohol program means a program for dispensing doses of liquor to individuals who experience harms related to their consumption of alcohol.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health authority may, without a licence or permit, purchase liquor for use in a managed alcohol program.

A person who administers a managed alcohol program may, without a licence or permit, serve and sell liquor in a public or private place to individuals participating in the program if the program is approved by a health authority.
Subject to subsection (5), a person who is authorized to serve and sell liquor under subsection (3) may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deliver the liquor in unopened containers to individuals participating in a managed alcohol program, and
enclose the liquor in containers and deliver the liquor to individuals participating in a managed alcohol program.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may deliver containers of liquor under subsection (4) only to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a place referred to in section 73 (1) (a), (b) or (f) of the Act, or
a dwelling place of an individual participating in a managed alcohol program, including a shelter for individuals experiencing homelessness.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An individual participating in a managed alcohol program may, without a licence or permit,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: purchase liquor from a person who is authorized to sell liquor under subsection (3), and
for the purposes of section 73 (1) (d) of the Act, consume doses of liquor, or possess liquor in an open container, in a place where the doses are served, sold or delivered under this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may, without a licence or permit, manufacture beer or wine for the purposes of a managed alcohol program if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the program is approved by a health authority,
the person's manufacture of the beer or wine is not in contravention of the Excise Act (Canada) or the Excise Act, 2001 (Canada), and
the beer or wine that is manufactured is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: consumed by individuals participating in the program, or
disposed of as waste.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Auctions for charitable purposes — small quantities of liquor

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a person may sell liquor by auction without a licence or permit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is a non-profit corporation or a representative of a non-profit organization,
the purpose of the auction is to raise funds for a charitable purpose, and
the person offers no more than the following quantities of liquor for sale at the auction:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 6 litres of spirits;
18 litres of wine, other than cider;
51.2 litres of one or more of beer, cider or coolers made from wine or spirits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A non-profit corporation or a representative of a non-profit organization must not sell liquor under subsection (1) within the 30 days following a previous sale of liquor by auction under subsection (1) by the non-profit corporation or any representative of the non-profit organization.
Sections 128 to 131 apply to an auction held under subsection (1) and a reference in those sections to a charitable auction must be read as a reference to an auction held under subsection (1).
In this section, "delivery service" means a business primarily engaged in the transportation of people or goods.
An owner of or person who works for a delivery service may, subject to the conditions set out in subsection (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: purchase liquor on behalf of a customer from a liquor store or any licensee who is authorized to sell liquor in unopened containers, and
deliver and sell the liquor to the customer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The conditions for the purposes of subsection (2) are the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner or worker purchases the liquor to be delivered after the customer has placed the order for the liquor;
the charge to the customer is no more than the price the owner or worker paid for the liquor plus a delivery service charge;
the owner or worker is an adult;
the owner or worker provides the customer with a delivery receipt that includes the

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: name and address of the customer,
date of the purchase,
price of the liquor,
time of delivery, and
delivery service charge;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner keeps a copy of the delivery receipt for one year after the date of purchase and provides it to the general manager or peace officer for inspection on request;
the owner or worker does not contravene section 75 or 77 (1) (a) of the Act;
the delivery is made to a place where liquor may be legally possessed or consumed;
the delivery does not take place between 11:30 p.m. and 9 a.m., unless authorized by the general manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A customer of a delivery service may purchase liquor from the owner of or a person who works for the delivery service.

The leader of members of a religion may, without a licence or permit, possess wine in an open container and consume the wine in a regular place of worship if the possession and consumption is for the purposes of a religious ceremony.

A person who attends a regular place of worship may, without a licence or permit, consume wine in the place of worship for the purposes of a religious ceremony if the wine is provided by a leader of members of the religion.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Sale and distribution of cooking alcohol

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, "cooking alcohol" means a substance referred to in section 10 (1) of the Act that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a distilled spirit made from fermented rice, and
contains at least 10% alcohol by volume.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 10 (4) of the Act, the general manager must direct that cooking alcohol be sold and distributed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: through liquor stores, or
by a person authorized by the general manager subject to the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the sale and distribution of the cooking alcohol is for manufacturing or commercial purposes and not for further sale or distribution;
the cooking alcohol is sold or distributed in containers of not less than 10 litres.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Bylaws Dealing with the Consumption of Liquor in a Public Place

bcl:section.bcl:text: A bylaw under section 73 (2) of the Act designating a public place as a place where liquor may be consumed must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require the person responsible for the public place to post signs setting out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the boundaries of the public place, and
the hours that liquor may be consumed, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: describe the number and size of the signs and how they are to be posted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ways to give or serve documents — general

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 68 (1) of the Act, a document that is required or allowed under the Act to be given or served on a person, other than the general manager, must be given or served in accordance with this section.
If a person is an individual, the ways to give or serve a document are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with the individual,
by leaving the document at the individual's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the individual,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the address at which the individual resides or to a forwarding address provided by the individual,
by leaving the document in a mailbox or mail slot for the address at which the individual resides,
by attaching the document to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the individual resides,
by sending the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the individual, or
by transmitting the document to a fax number provided by the individual.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is a corporation, the ways to give or serve a document are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with an officer or director of the corporation,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the registered office of the corporation,
by sending a copy of the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the corporation, or
by transmitting a copy of the document to a fax number provided by the corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is a partnership, the ways to give or serve a document are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with a partner,
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the business office of the partnership,
by sending a copy of the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address provided by the partnership, or
by transmitting a copy of the document to a fax number provided by the partnership.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a person is a licensee, additional ways to give or serve a document are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with an individual who works in the establishment,
by sending the document by ordinary mail or registered mail to the mailing address of the licensee as set out in the licence, or
by leaving the document in a mailbox or mail slot at a business address provided by the licensee.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 68 (2) of the Act, a document given or served in accordance with section 198 of this regulation is conclusively deemed to be received,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is left with an individual, on the day it is left,
if the document is sent by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier, on the 5th day after it is mailed or received by the courier,
if the document is left in a mailbox or mail slot, on the 3rd day after it is left,
if the document is attached to a door or other conspicuous place, on the 3rd day after it is attached,
if the document is sent by electronic mail, on the 3rd day after it is sent, and
if the document is transmitted to a fax number, on the 3rd day after it is transmitted.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ways to give or serve documents on general manager
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 68 (1) of the Act, a document that is required or allowed under the Act to be given or served on the general manager must be given or served in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document with the general manager;
by sending the document by ordinary mail, registered mail or courier to the address of the general manager;
by sending the document by electronic mail to the electronic mail address of the general manager;
by transmitting the document to a fax number of the general manager.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The fees payable under the Act and this regulation are set out in Schedule 1.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), all fees must be paid at the time that an application or request for anything referred to in Schedule 1 is submitted.

The fees for the first year of a licence, other than the first year of a food primary licence, and the fees for a special event permit may be paid after the application is submitted, but must be paid before the licence or permit is issued.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the term of a new licence is greater or less than one year, the fee payable for the first year of the licence must be pro-rated on a monthly basis as though the term of the new licence began on the first day of the month in which the licence is issued and ended on the last day of the month in which the licence expires.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Calculation of renewal fee based on liquor purchases and sales

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to the calculation of the renewal fee for liquor primary, food primary, catering, licensee retail store, wine store, special wine store and rural licensee retail store licences set out in item 19 of Schedule 1.
For the purposes of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: liquor purchases do not include any purchase by a licensee from another licensee that is authorized by the terms and conditions of the purchaser's licence, and
liquor sales do not include any sale from a licensee to another licensee that is authorized by the terms and conditions of the seller's licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), the renewal fee is based on the amount spent on liquor purchases by the licensee in the 12-month period that ends 6 months before the expiry of the licence.

If a licensee who holds a wine store licence is required by the terms and conditions to report to the general manager the amount the licensee receives from the sales of liquor, the renewal fee for the wine store licence is based on the amount of the liquor sales in the 12-month period that ends 6 months before the expiry of the licence.

If the operations of a licensee started less than 18 months before the expiration of the licence being renewed, the amount to be used as the amount spent on liquor purchases or the amount received from liquor sales for the 12-month period that ends 6 months before the expiration of the licence is calculated in accordance with the following:

the total amount spent on liquor purchases or received from liquor sales by the licensee during the 12-month period;
the number of days calculated by determining the months that the licensee was in operation during the 12-month period and then totaling the number of days in those months.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When fees for change of name not payable
bcl:section.bcl:text: No fees are payable in respect of a change to a name of the licensee or the establishment if the application is made at the same time as an application for a transfer or conversion of a licence.

Fees paid by an applicant for a reconsideration of a section 51 order under section 53.1 (1) of the Act must be refunded if the reconsideration order made under section 53.1 (9) of the Act rescinds the section 51 order.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Conversion to Rural Licensee Retail Store Licence

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Conversion of rural agency store appointment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: appointment means an appointment under section 18 (5) of the Liquor Distribution Act to operate a rural agency store;
licence means a rural licensee retail store licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On February 26, 2021, an appointment is converted to a licence if the following requirements are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appointee has made a request for the conversion;
the appointee is not a minor or, if the appointee is a corporation, minors own less than 10 percent of the corporation's shares;

the general manager is satisfied that the appointee has disclosed to the general manager any association with, connection with or financial interest in a liquor manufacturer or the liquor manufacturer's agent that is likely to lead the appointee to promote the sale of liquor of the manufacturer;
the appointee owns the business in respect of which the appointment is converted to a licence;
the appointee

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is the owner of the place or premises in respect of which the appointment is converted to a licence, or

has an arrangement that the general manager determines gives the appointee a degree of control over the place or premises in respect of which the appointment is converted to a licence that will allow the appointee to comply with the requirements relating to establishments set out in the Act, this regulation and the terms and conditions of the licence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For certainty, section 70.4 (1) [initial requirements] does not apply to the conversion of an appointment to a licence under this section.

Section 70.5 (b) [location at least 10 km from another store] does not apply to a licence that is converted under this section from an appointment if the rural licensee retail store under the licence is in the same location as the rural agency store under the appointment.
Section 70.6 [ownership] does not apply to a licence that is converted under this section from an appointment if the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the date of the appointment's conversion, the rural agency store under the appointment is not, in the opinion of the general manager, independently owned;
the store in which the rural licensee retail store under the licence is located has the same owner as the rural agency store under the appointment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 202 (2) [time for payment of fees], an appointee whose appointment is converted to a licence under this section is not required to pay the fee for the first year of the licence.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Schedule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: licensee includes a former licensee and a deemed licensee referred to in section 52 of the Act;
permittee includes a former permittee referred to in section 53 of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A contravention in respect of a licensee refers to a licensee's contravention of a provision of the Act or this regulation, or a licensee's failure to comply with a term or condition of the licence, that is set out under the heading "Contravention" in the table to this Schedule.

A contravention in respect of a permittee refers to a permittee's contravention of a provision of the Act or this regulation, or a permittee's failure to comply with a term or condition of the permit, that is set out under the heading "Contravention" in the table to this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A contravention is of the same type as another contravention if each contravention falls within the same item in the table to this Schedule.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: First, second and subsequent contraventions — licensee

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A contravention is a first contravention in respect of a licensee if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contravention was committed at or in respect of an establishment under the licensee's licence or an event site under an authorization held by the licensee, and

the licensee has not committed a contravention of the same type at or in respect of that establishment or any event site under an authorization held by the licensee within the 24-month period preceding the commission of the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A contravention is a second contravention in respect of a licensee if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contravention was committed at or in respect of an establishment under the licensee's licence or an event site under an authorization held by the licensee, and

the licensee has committed one contravention of the same type at or in respect of that establishment or any event site under an authorization held by the licensee within the 24-month period preceding the commission of the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A contravention is a subsequent contravention in respect of a licensee if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contravention was committed at or in respect of an establishment under the licensee's licence or an event site under an authorization held by the licensee, and

the licensee has committed a second contravention of the same type at or in respect of that establishment or any event site under an authorization held by the licensee within the 24-month period preceding the commission of the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the general manager is satisfied that imposing the monetary penalty or period of suspension for a second or subsequent contravention set out in the table to this Schedule would create undue hardship on a licensee, the general manager may impose a monetary penalty or period of suspension set out in the table to this Schedule for a first contravention.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The columns for second and subsequent contraventions under the heading "Monetary Penalty" in the table to this Schedule do not apply to a permittee and the monetary penalty to be imposed on a permittee is the one set out in the column for a first contravention under the heading "Monetary Penalty" even if the permittee has committed more than one contravention of the same type.
